results.title: Kuelap Design System
results.overview: Kuelap provides tech banking solutions mainly for micro, small, and medium enterprises. As their platforms grew, it became clear that design inconsistencies across different products were negatively impacting the user experience and making it difficult for new designers and developers to quickly integrate and contribute to the team.

article.content: When I joined Kuelap, the company was already managing three distinct platforms, each with unique functionality and designed for different devices:

list.content: Core Banking System (CBS), on desktop browser, to manage co-op banking system.
Member Service Application (MSA), on tablet, for co-op members administration.
Octo Mobile, on mobile, for self-service banking by co-op members.

article.content: Each of these three platforms also have their own style and color scheme. I was tasked with contributing to a scalable and consistent design system to streamline the design between existing and future platforms, ensuring brand consistency and improving collaboration between design and development teams.
The lack of a unified design system led to inconsistencies across the product interface. Each designer and developer often recreated similar components, which resulted in:

list.content: Inconsistent UI elements across various parts of the product.
Redundant design efforts and code duplication.

article.content: The first step was to conduct an extensive audit of the existing UI components and patterns. This included:

list.content: Reviewing all screens to identify common components like buttons, form elements, modals, etc.
Understanding variations in typography, spacing, color schemes, and grid structures.
Analyzing how these elements behaved across different platforms and devices.

article.content: To ensure cross-team collaboration, we created a detailed style guide that included:

list.content: Color Palette: Primary, secondary, and neutral colors, along with accessibility considerations for contrast. With Kuelap orange as the primary brand color.
Typography: Font styles, sizes, and spacing guidelines for various use cases.
Icons: A unified iconography set with consistent sizing, line weights, and alignment.

article.content: Next, we designed a modular and flexible set of UI components. Each component was crafted with scalability and adaptability in mind.
To ensure the design system was adopted by all team members, we created comprehensive documentation that covered:

list.content: Guidelines on how to use components.
List of available variants for each components.
Examples for guiding team members.
Conflicting priorities: It can be difficult to find time to focus on the design system, as other features and design initiatives often take precedence and demand higher priority.

Balancing consistency and flexibility: Striking the right balance between consistency and flexibility in the design system proved to be a challenge. It wasn’t easy to ensure the system was adaptable enough to support various products and use cases while still maintaining a cohesive and consistent design throughout.
Integrating legacy designs: We faced the challenge of integrating legacy designs and components that had built up over time, and aligning them with the new design system was a difficult process.

Handling fear of change: Implementing a new design system can disrupt teams that are accustomed to established workflows. Managing the transition and offering sufficient support and resources to help teams adjust to the new system is key to overcome this challenge.

article.content: With the design system ready, we implemented the styles and components to our platforms with various phases to ensure smooth transition to the new designs. Eventually, we will implement the styles and components to all of Kuelap's platforms.

article.label: Core Banking System, styles and components implemented
Octo Mobile, styles and components implemented

article.content: As Kuelap evolves with more platforms, the design system will be continuously improved to ensure it remains relevant and effective.

results.title: VALORANT App
results.overview: The weapon skins in VALORANT Store are being sold as four items shelf and rotating on a daily basis. The skins can only be checked when you logged in the game. Because of this, there were so many times I was unable to check the store whenever I want to due to being away from PC. What if we can easily check the store everywhere we go?

article.content: The weapon skins in VALORANT Store are being sold as four items shelf and rotating on a daily basis. The skins can only be checked when you logged in the game. Because of this, there were so many times I was unable to check the store whenever I want to due to being away from PC. What if we can easily check the store everywhere we go?

article.label: Design process used in this case study

article.content: I began this case study with problem assumptions. These assumptions was based on my own experience with the problem and with further explorations.

list.content: Checking VALORANT store can only be done in the game. Let’s say you are on a vacation and want to check today’s VALORANT store rotation. If you use a laptop to play, you will need to find a table and boot up your laptop just to check it. If you use a Gaming PC, unless you are dedicated enough to bring all those peripherals to your vacation then you are out of luck.

Buying VALORANT skins can only be done in the game. VALORANT skins are rotated on a daily basis. Once you missed buying a skin you are looking for, you will have to wait for a random number of days for the skin to appear in the store.

article.content: I reached out to 10 participants to validate the assumptions I made about the problem, and to see if there were any other issues I missed. I interviewed fellow players who had been playing VALORANT frequently. Occasionally, I even conducted interviews while playing VALORANT matches. It might seem a bit unusual to interview during the chaos of a 5v5 game, but the participants seemed excited to talk about the weapon skins I used. I believe this is a good enough justification for doing interviews during matches.

list.content: Do you love using skins? How often do you check the store?
Tell me about your experience of checking the store. Anything frustrating or challenging about checking the store?
Are there any other features besides the store and playing the game that you check often?

article.content: Surprisingly, 3 out of 10 participants have more than one account to play with. One particular participant use many accounts with the intention of selling them (which is a bannable offense, don’t try it). Majority of the participants love using weapon skins and checked the skin store quite often. Four of them said they couldn’t log in to check the daily rotation because they weren't near their PC.
When asked about other features to check, these are the top three and here’s what participants have to say about them:
"I always can’t wait for the next Night.Market. Hope I won’t get any Smite skins tho."
"I’m just hoping for a good skins with discount."
"Aside from buddies and cards, Battle Pass is how I get Radianite Points to upgrade skins without paying the full price."
"I jumped into VALORANT pretty late and I missed many Battle Pass cards, titles, and buddies I wanted. Accessories Store and Kingdom Credits give me another chance of getting those stuff."
Based on the user interviews and my own experience, I found 3 types of VALORANT Skin users. I assigned a VALORANT agent to each of these persona, reflected by their character traits and voicelines.

list.content: Just started to buy weapon skins - PHOENIX
Already bought some weapon skins but looking to buy more - YORU
Have a great number of weapon skins collection - CHAMBER

article.label: VALORANT Phoenix player card by Riot Games

article.content: "Chamber! I'm ready for some custom guns. You'll hook me up, yeah?"
PHOENIX just starting to get into the skin game, he will login at least once a day hoping for Ion Sheriff to appear.
Will beg you to drop your Kuronami Vandal every round.
At least got a weapon skin for meta weapons like Vandal, still using the default one for less desirable weapons like Ares.

article.label: VALORANT Yoru player card by Riot Games

article.content: "What brand are your knives, Jett? They're not 'Mammoth'. 'Segreto', maybe? I need one for my collection."
YORU have collected a good amount of weapon skins, but still have the itch to collect more.
Have skins for most of his weapons.
Already have the classics like Prime Vandal. Looking to get any Champion skins.

article.label: VALORANT Chamber player card by Riot Games

article.content: "These guns we use are okay but I will also bring my own. No offense."
CHAMBER has bought every exclusive or hyped skin bundles on their first day of appearance.
All his weapons has at least 4 choices of weapon skins.
Not the one who begs for skin drop. Why beg when you have them all?
After doing the research, I feel confident on defining the pain points from the user interviews.

Pain Point #1: Need PC to check VALORANT store rotations
My initial assumption turned out to be true to some participants. Some of them feels they need a way to easily check without having to login from their PC. This also applies to buying VALORANT points.

Pain Point #2: Need PC to check various features in VALORANT
The pain point of needing to use PC also applies to other features well. Most participants were talking excitedly about the next Night.Market. Some of them also likes checking the Battle Pass and the accessories shop as well.

With these pain points in mind, I moved on with the idea of designing a VALORANT mobile app where you can check the store rotations, the Night.Market, the Battle Pass, the Accessories Store, and buy VALORANT points.
I use user flow to ideate what can the app do and what each menu functions will have.
With UI sketches, I imagined how the app main pages would look like.

In 2023 before starting the research, I already created a design system for VALORANT App with components ready for the main store and buying points. I made a design system for this so I would have easier effort to grow and adapt the project alongside the game current state of development and future updates. I’ve added new components mainly for the Battle Pass, Accessories Store, and Night.Market.
With the design system updated, I combined the proposed user flows, UI sketches, and the design system to create the UI design.

Pain points addressed: Need PC to check VALORANT store rotations. Players can just use this app whenever they need to check daily store rotations. They can also use this app to buy the skin they need, provided they have enough VALORANT points.

Pain points addressed: Need PC to check various features in VALORANT. Players can also use this app to check the Battle Pass progress and see if they have any item they want. They can also check the Accessories Store which are updated weekly.

Pain points addressed: Need PC to check various features in VALORANT. Night.Market can also be checked in the app as long as it is active in the game, usually once every Act (a VALORANT Act will last around two months).

Pain points addressed: Need PC to check VALORANT store rotations & Need PC to check various features in VALORANT. There will be moments when players don’t have enough VALORANT Points. They can buy points in the app so they won’t miss out the weapon skin they want.
After several steps of iterations in the UI Design, I made a prototype using Figma for usability testing.

<iframe style='border: 1px solid rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);'' width='800' height='450' src='https://embed.figma.com/proto/WdavpyNDNe55rZihxJV701/%F0%9F%8E%AEValorant-Store-App?page-id=28%3A2&node-id=402-1348&node-type=canvas&viewport=402%2C76%2C0.04&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=402%3A1348&embed-host=share' allowfullscreen></iframe>
To validate the designs, I conducted usability tests with 4 participants who were frequent VALORANT players. These are the tasks I asked them to do:

list.content: Buy the current skin bundle
Get more VALORANT Points
Buy a daily skin offer
Upgrade the Battle Pass
Buy something from the Accessories Store
Buy an item in the Night.Market

article.content: Long story short, they completed the tasks easily, encountering only minor issues along the way:

list.content: Access to Night.Market, when available, was too small to be noticed the first time.

Few participants was not aware at first that they need to tap the VALORANT Point currency to access Point Store page. The call-to-action access in the main store seems to be helping resolve this issue.

article.content: Despite the minor hiccups, all participants managed to find access for these pages eventually.
Participants also shared positive feedbacks during the usability testing.
"Nice, I can check for Oni Katana easily using this app."
"Great design! Hope they will develop this into an app for real."

When I worked on this project, I was wondering if it’s possible to actually develop the app for this project. Then I found out that Riot is not releasing official API for player account store rotations. The data for these are considered private confidential information. Right now, there is no way to handle the app through third-party developers unless it’s being done by Riot themselves.

I also managed to talk again with previous user interview participants. A few of them who are used to check VALORANT store consistently are now satisfied with their current collection and are not actively checking anymore. These are examples of how the PHOENIX and the YORU could become the CHAMBER (the user personas). So in a way, I understand if Riot might have some ideas about the concept but isn’t prioritizing its development at the moment.
Even so, I love research and design process and I love VALORANT as well. To be able to combine both was a rewarding challenge for me. That’s what really matters to me in the end.

During the discover and the iterate process, a few of the participants talks about checking and buying Agents inside the app. Since these Agents can be bought with Kingdom Credits, it got me thinking about an idea: “What if users can use the app to get Kingdom Credits?”. Here’s possible user activities in the app that can be used for this sort of loyalty program:

list.content: Buying weapon skin in the app
Top up VALORANT points
Opening the Night.Market cards

article.content: This Kingdom Credits loyalty program might hopefully give some incentive for players to spend money using the app. This program might entice the CHAMBER to buy more fine addition his collection too.
Additionally, I mentioned before that I planned to adapt any changes and update that Riot apply to VALORANT. So this app design project will keep evolving alongside the game.

DISCLAIMER: I don’t work for Riot Games or have any affiliation with Riot Games at all. The main goal of this case study is to blend my passion for VALORANT with everything I have learned as a UX/UI Designer.

results.title: Self-Service Laundry App
results.overview: The self-service laundry app in this case study offers a convenient and efficient way to manage your laundry. Users can easily pay for laundry services through the app, lock and unlock machines to ensure security, and receive real-time notifications when their laundry cycle is complete.

article.content: When I was still in Berkeley, I frequent a coin self-service laundry (usually called laundromat in Bay Area) once every 2 weeks. There was this one time when I forgot to bring coins and cash. I have to get back to my house 3 blocks away to get them. Probably there’s more problem for laundromat users, or laundry in general?
I decided to create a solution to my inconvenience.

article.label: Design process used in this case study

article.content: I began with user interviews to discover general problems about laundry. The interview was conducted inside self-service establishment and to users who had used other forms of self-service laundry. Because of this, the interviews showed more problems about self-service laundry.
These are common problems I found during the interviews.

list.content: Forgot to bring coins to coin laundromat
Credit card being stuck inside machine
Forgot that they had laundry going on for the whole day
Not enough washing and drying machine
Unattended laundry (or leftovers) inside machine, therefore unable to use machine

article.content: All participants I interviewed seems to fall into this type of persona.
After doing the research, I feel confident on defining the problems of self-service laundry.

Pain Point #1: Payment Problems
The payment problems ranges from forgetting to bring coins to credit cards getting stuck on machine.

Pain Point #2: Unattended Laundry Results on Time Wasting
One participant mentioned frustration with unattended laundry occupying all the machines, preventing them from doing their own laundry.

Pain Point #3: Forgetting Laundry
One of the participants completely forgot about their laundry and left it for an entire day.

Pain Point #4: Laundry being Taken Out Without Permission
A participant shared an incident where someone had placed their wet laundry on the floor. Yikes.
I brainstormed several solutions to solve the pain points I defined earlier.

Solution #1: Payment App
This app could be used to store balance and get coins, in case users forgot their wallet. Users could use the app to scan QR codes in washers and dryers to do payment. They could also scan QR codes on coin machines to get quarter coins.

Solution #2: Laundry Alert System
Alert system will alert users of their impending laundry. The system could be an app, email, or text messages. This way, users won’t have to forget about their laundry.

Solution #3: Special Laundry Card
The special card solution is just another way of solving payment. The card can be used to store balances that could be used to pay laundry.
I explored the solutions more using paper sketches of each solutions.

article.label: I'll be honest, I didn't sketch the third solution since it's only a card, ..right?

article.content: I spread an online survey between students of UC Berkeley, SurveySwap with USA as respondent residency, and Survey sharing 2019 Facebook group.

According to the survey, self-service laundry is still relevant to 73,1% of the survey participants. Participants also showed more interest towards payment app solution. With these research in mind, I moved on to prototype stage with the payment app solution.

I started the prototype stage with a co-design session with some designer friends. The goal of this session is to brainstorm the basic functions of the app. These are the proposed scenarios from the co-design session.
Here are the UI designs based on the proposed scenarios and paper sketches. These UI designs are made using Adobe XD.

list.content: Pain point addressed: Payment problems
Scan QR codes to do payment and get coins.
Save credit cards for future payments.
Pain point addressed: Laundry being taken out without permission
Locking will open or close whenever user scan the QR code.
Prevent anyone from taking out laundry without permission.
A penalty system for leaving the locked laundry for too long, so it’s fair for everyone.
Pain point addressed: Unattended laundry results on time wasting, forgetting laundry
Users will be alerted 5 minutes before their laundry is done.
The alerts would theoretically minimized unattended laundry.

article.content: After several steps of iterations on the final design, I made a clickable prototype using Adobe XD for the future usability testing.
When working on this project, I realised more opportunities to test the app limit that I haven’t think of before, such as:

list.content: What if I put a loyalty program to reward users for keep using this app?
What if I could buy detergent using the app?

article.content: For this project to completely solve the laundry problem, there has to be more research and development for the laundry machine themselves. How the machines read the laundry requirements from the app? How the machines send signal to users phone to alert about their impending laundry? How do the locking mechanism works? An app for payment and tracking laundry won’t be complete without the laundry machines to connect with it.

For now, the project only covers the UI design from user interview to clickable prototype. I would like to do usability testing on the prototype and see if there's any friction point identifed in the prototype. I also planned to do more research on how to integrate this prototype to laundry machines.
Thank you for reading, here’s a little background

This case study is part of User Research for UX course challenge from UC Berkeley Extension. It’s a challenge that covers the whole 8 week course. Some of the fellow classmates here are also UX field professionals in Bay Area. It was an incredible opportunity that lets me have a conversation about my design to these fellow classmates.

results.overview: This part will showcases some design explorations I've done across the years. I had fun doing these.

article.content: These are user interface explorations I’ve worked on over the years. Some might offer solutions to real world problems, even if they may never see light of the day.
When I’m not doing research or UI design, I play around with visual designs. These can be logos, stationery, anything. It’s just pure fun when I don’t have to actively solve problems with these.
